I can confidently tell readers that Harry Potter and the Cursed Child beats them all.

Hooray! With 'Harry Potter and the Cursed Child,' the Boy Who Lived has finally come to Broadway, bringing enchantment to a world that could really use a little magic right now.
Slackly structured, verbose, stylistically muddled, overwrought mishmash.

Surprises in production, with director Michael Mayer and his team altogether littering the stage with jokes and gags and gimmicks which grow, like a snowball, until just about everything gets a laugh.

Not, if you’re smart, by trying to repeat it. Not as feel-good nostalgia or a lovingly curated museum piece, heaven forbid; but as a raucous, pull-you-in-and-leave-you-prostrate-with-laughter joyride.
Bette Midler is so good in Hello, Dolly! that she makes you forget anyone else ever played the role.
Midler's return to Broadway after more than 30 years is a triumph of star power and old-fashioned musical theater craft
Ms. Midler doesn't just stop the show; she picks it up, shakes it and makes it sparkle like fresh snow in sunlight.
Midler's performance is a marvel of comic timing and emotional intelligence, bringing fresh life to a role that could easily feel dated.
I think it gives this 'Dolly' a fascinating new valence.

Hell's Kitchen, based on the early life and song catalog of Alicia Keys, is a heaven-sent new musical that seems destined for a long and successful run on Broadway.

Lively choreography and powerhouse vocal performances...overcome a so-so story.
Hell's Kitchen succeeds as both a jukebox musical and a coming-of-age story, anchored by powerhouse performances that bring Alicia Keys' music to vivid life on stage.

It’s one of the few shows on Broadway with consistently phenomenal voices from stage veterans and debut makers alike — all of whom are performing the 15-time Grammy Award winner’s music and lyrics. No matter one’s opinion of Keys, she is an undeniably accomplished composer whose music has quickly become part of the cultural zeitgeist.
Lively choreography and powerhouse vocal performances...overcome a so-so story.

Along with choreographer Camille A. Brown, whose dances burst with unrestrained youth and Manhattan chutzpah, the director gives Ninth Ave’s unique bustle energy without resorting to old cliches. It’s a show that’s true to its city.

Still and all, the secret sauce of this entertainment package is choreographer Camille A. Brown. While many a show highlights athletic, exuberant street dance in all its forms, Brown is determined to tell story through dance. Her ensemble is never there just to show off, but participates to reflect ...

There’s no rags-to-riches transformation. No journey from street-corner singer to stadium sellout. No diva drama. 'Hell’s Kitchen' is simply a 1990s-set coming-of-age piece...More than anything, ‘Hell’s Kitchen’ is a New York story.
If only all of Keys' songs fit so easily into Kristoffer Diaz's libretto.
Hell's Kitchen is a musical that pulses with the authentic energy of New York City, featuring powerhouse vocals and a story that feels both personal and universal.

“Hell’s Kitchen” is a very high end jukebox musical, Direction (Michael Greif), Choreography (Camille A. Brown) plus costumes, sets, lighting — they’re all top notch. What would have made this show something extra? A real book, more than cardboard cut outs of characters. Allie wants is a boyfriend, which she gets. Big deal.

It has probably the best music currently on Broadway, sung by a top-notch cast of talented performers. Keys' memory lane to a time when an angsty, kinda troubled, kinda naïve, teenage girl battles with her single white mom, her absent Black dad, her burgeoning hormones and her unclear sense of self is, frankly, a really good show.
As Ali, Moon is simply astonishing in her Broadway debut, and she commands the stage like a seasoned rock star

This is a show that knows exactly what it wants to be and achieves it with remarkable consistency and style, powered by Keys's songs and a cast that treats every moment as though their lives depend on it.
The musical succeeds in translating Keys' deeply personal story into an affecting coming-of-age tale that resonates beyond the specifics of her experience.
Lively choreography and powerhouse vocal performances...overcome a so-so story.
The show is at its best when it focuses on the mother-daughter relationship at its core, powered by two exceptional performances from Maleah Joi Moon and Shoshana Bean.

This can only hold for so long, though, and, with 24 numbers, the show is overloaded with music. While the production places singers back at the fore of musical theatre (imagine!) Diaz’s book needs more room to breathe.
Lively choreography and powerhouse vocal performances...overcome a so-so story.

worth being wary of any musical that positions itself as a love letter to New York City.

“Although the show does incorporate live guitar and drums at certain times, it relies mainly on prerecorded music. The immersive musical about Imelda Marcos transforms the Broadway Theatre into a disco-political fever dream that demands audience participation while never losing sight of its dark historical truths.
There is room for so much to go physically wrong at ‘Here Lies Love,’ but Timbers chews through the 360-degree challenge, offering dazzling spectacle from any angle.
The real pull of ‘Here Lies Love’ is the staging, with a malleable performance space, an audience herded to and fro, and cast members finding perches throughout the venue.

Here Lies Love succeeds as both a thrilling piece of immersive theater and a pointed political statement, even if its disco-ball dazzle occasionally threatens to overshadow its more serious intentions.

“You can sit and observe the show all around you or you can pay to hit the orchestra floor and party with the Marcoses. Whee!...At no more than 100 minutes long, ‘Here Lies Love’ never over-indulges nor does it lose the audience’s attention for a moment. “
Director Alex Timbers' ingenious staging puts the audience in the middle the action.
David Byrne's immersive disco musical about Imelda Marcos is a knockout that turns Broadway into a dance floor.

The show is absolutely an indictment of the autocratic Marcos administration...If you really want to immerse yourself in Imelda’s world, go for the floor. You might find yourself shaking hands with the candidates on the campaign trail, joining in a line dance, or even holding up your own laban sign.

‘Here Lies Love’ remains an impressive and effective experience; but uptown on Broadway, at the over-sized Broadway, the bloom is off the rose of Tacloban...Regretfully, we conclude that the uptown edition—as of the official opening—is not yet quite so powerful as what enthralled us, three times, down on Astor Place.

Audience members whose knowledge of Imelda Marcos is limited to the fact that she owned 3,000 pairs of shoes will only leave with a partial understanding of this violent period. The musical has no book, and the punchy songs paint broad strokes of the 60-year history... Still, this rollicking, form-breaking musical party is well worth an RSVP.

Immersive theater should feel participatory and intriguing, but right from the beginning Here Lies Love (Broadway Theatre, booking to Sept 3) feels hectoring—before ultimately becoming a big, baffling Broadway mess.

Here Lies Love is an ambitious, immersive musical that transforms the Broadway Theatre into a dancefloor-cum-dictator origin story, though its political complexities sometimes get lost in the spectacle.
The show succeeds in making the audience complicit in the Marcoses' rise to power, forcing us to reckon with our own susceptibility to charismatic authoritarianism.

‘Here Lies Love’ bets that glamour can make up for narrative — or, rather, that in a show about the dangers of political demagogy, glamour itself is the narrative. It’s a case of form follows function into the fire. We are drawn to cultural and political excitement in much the same, often dangerous way.

: Besides the great songs, with music by Byrne and Fatboy Slim and lyrics by Byrne - the alluring title number might become permanently lodged in your brain - there's inventive choreography by Annie-B Parson, eye-catching, quick-change costumes designed by Clint Ramos, Justin Townsend's atmospheric lighting scheme and David Korins' remarkably en...
What may be most remarkable about ‘Here Lies Love’ is how deftly it pivots from the celebratory and even sentimental presentation of Imelda’s rise to the inevitably condemnatory

Since the show is more party than parable, the management might want to consider a few more minutes of music after the curtain calls. Because ‘Here Lies Love’ is the kind of stimulant that makes you believe you could dance all night.

“I’d still recommend prospective ticket buyers to pick the floor for one simple reason: It’s an experience unlike any other you’ve ever had on Broadway. The amount of thought, planning, detail, and money that went into this is insane, and it’s not hyperbole to say that you won’t believe your eyes.

It asks us to embody the ambition, mendacity, and ruthlessness we carry with us, even when we think we’ve danced them off, and question our complicity. After the non-stop party, the show’s sobering end reminds us that dancing can be as inattentive as it is cathartic.
‘Here Lies Love’ isn’t about Ferdinand or Imelda or even a bygone Philippines. It’s all about Alex Timbers.

Our complicity with such cycles of populist fervor—whether, depending on your ticket, as spectators from a safe distance or as extras in a mob scene—is the loudly beating heart of ‘Here Lies Love,’ a party that hides a mordant critique of civilization and its discotheques.
Byrne and Fatboy Slim’s sung-through score is the star of the 90-minute production, a hypnotic churn of synth beats, funky rhythms and pop momentum that aims squarely for the pelvis.

...the crowd itself is ‘Here Lies Love’s’ main character, this mass of people looking to be appeased by a good performance, no matter who’s singing the political karaoke. The show ends with democracy, but it has a wary relationship with the masses. The thought may be that, lured by a beat good enough, they’ll dance along to anything.
This musical feels more like a support-group meeting than a Broadway show.
The musical 'High,' which opened on Tuesday night at the Booth Theater, is a well-intentioned but ultimately earthbound effort to dramatize the struggles of addiction and recovery.
The show feels less like a fully realized musical than like a tentative first draft of one.
With this production, these actors, this marriage, a little bit is a lot.

Think of it as Private Lives involving Public Figures. A remarkable performance by Laurie Metcalf and quite a sympathetic one by John Lithgow, two superb actors playing at the top of their exceptional games in the title roles, make this offbeat comedy a must-see for savvy viewers who cannot be bothered with the usual tourist crap on Broadway.
The play works best when it focuses on the marriage at its center, with Metcalf and Lithgow finding moments of genuine intimacy amid the political calculation.
While the play's exploration of power, ambition and marriage provides intermittent rewards, the drama feels more like an extended Saturday Night Live sketch than a penetrating character study.
This biodrama about the Clintons during the 2008. Democratic primary feels both rushed and static, despite committed performances by Laurie Metcalf and John Lithgow.

Laurie Metcalf and John Lithgow are superb as the political power couple in Lucas Hnath's smart, speculative drama
This is comfort food of the highest order — familiar, satisfying and executed with skill and obvious affection.
The show is a pleasant enough diversion that should appeal to audiences nostalgic for simpler times, even if it never quite captures the effortless magic of the movie.
This resolutely old-fashioned musical adaptation of the 1942 movie feels less like comfort food than like leftovers that have been reheated once too often.
It's polished and pleasant. But a great gift to the theater season aborning it's not.
This cheerful but formulaic musical comedy based on the 1942 movie is as wholesome as apple pie and about as surprising.
This jukebox musical built around the songs of Tupac Shakur feels more like a lecture than a night of entertainment, weighed down by heavy-handed social messaging that overshadows the music.

This jukebox musical inspired by the songs of Tupac Shakur feels more like a sermon than a story, and its characters never acquire the specificity that would make us care about their individual fates.
The show's fatal flaw is that it never figures out how to dramatize Shakur's activist message.
The story is touching, but the ritualistic telling proves problematic. It’s done in large part through narration, often delivered in a poetical, incantational style that can be distancing.

Here, the lyrical opening passages of Home intended to evoke the long ago rural South are nearly lost in the breakneck speed they are spoken. Other poetic sections tend to rush by, too, suggesting that Leon doesn’t trust the audience to appreciate their beauty.
the play’s dramatic method prevents its grimmer parts from being fully effective.
This show is pure, unabashed entertainment — the kind of musical that makes you leave the theater with a big smile on your face.

Jason Robert Brown and Andrew Bergman have turned the 1992. Nicolas Cage romantic comedy into a surprisingly engaging musical that captures the manic energy of Las Vegas while delivering genuine heart.
This production is a real-live, old-fashioned, deeply satisfying Broadway musical in a way few new shows are anymore.

This cheerfully mindless musical comedy about a mama's boy who loses his fiancee in a poker game is so relentlessly upbeat that it's hard to resist its charms, even when your brain is screaming at you to show some taste.
The musical 'Honeymoon Motel' feels like an extended comedy sketch that has overstayed its welcome, despite some clever moments and energetic performances from its cast.
The Broadway musical 'Hot Feet,' which opened last night at the Hilton Theater, is not so much a show as a very expensive jukebox with some fancy stepping attached.
Parker remains the 17-year-old she was then. Remarkable! Her version of innocence assailed and fighting back is acting at a zenith.

When Paula Vogel’s Pulitzer Prize-winning How I Learned to Drive first opened off-Broadway back in 1997, the term “grooming” was still most often used to suggest tending to one’s appearance and hygiene—or to those of one’s pet.
The revival of Paula Vogel's Pulitzer Prize-winning play about sexual abuse is as devastating and complex as ever, with Mary-Louise Parker giving a performance of extraordinary nuance.

The production, starring Mary-Louise Parker and David Morse, brings a masterful delicacy to Paula Vogel's Pulitzer Prize-winning memory play about the relationship between a teenage girl and her uncle.
This revival of Paula Vogel's Pulitzer Prize-winning drama about sexual abuse is sensitively staged and superbly acted.
Vogel's script creates its own piercing language for assault, harassment and all the ways our society reinforces regressive ideas about gender, sex and consent.
Paula Vogel's Pulitzer Prize-winning memory play receives a faithful, expertly acted revival that honors both its delicate handling of trauma and its unsettling insights into the grooming process.
The production is sensitive and thoughtful, but it feels almost too careful, as if afraid to fully inhabit the complex emotional territory that makes Vogel's play so powerful.

Music should deepen this inquisition; characters can now sing through the difficult interactions that, in the documentary, they struggle to speak through. But the mundanity of Yandura’s indistinguishable score rarely coincides with the emotional ebbs and flows of Melocik’s lyrics. You never get the sense that this needs to be a musical at all.

One of the things ‘How In Ohio’ gets so splendidly right is the easy comfort with diversity these young people with autism are graced, as if they’ve long ago made peace with the very concept of outsiderdom.

“ ‘How to Dance in Ohio’ — which features sparse staging and hardly any costume changes until the big dance itself — often misses by trying to cover too much ground from too many different angles and perspectives. And the music as a whole is only okay.

All that said, “How to Dance in Ohio,” which features a book and lyrics by Rebekah Greer Melocik and music by Jacob Yandura, doesn’t always live up to its own aims. In particular, it tends to moralize and preach, to tell rather than show, when its real abilityto improve the world is in its specifics.

The show, directed by Sammi Cannold, waffles between being stalely predictable and taking confounding narrative leaps. The plot and dialogue are shoddy, and early on it becomes apparent that we are unfortunately sitting at a missed opportunity.

The young performers who make up the seven-member core – all of whom self-identify as autistic – do their best to make us, the audience, comfortable...The eleven-o’clock number goes to Liam Pearce as Drew, a mechanically minded savant. Spilling over with confidence and elan, Pearce seems born to the spotlight...He connects all right, big-time.

Audience members are likely to leave the Belasco with an exhilarating lift in their step, and that’s all to the good. But such enthusiasm will come from the talent of the performers and the worthiness of the message, rather than from the actual songs, story, or production of ‘How to Dance in Ohio’.

The production…has some tuneful melodies, some touching moments and, above all, an exhilarated and exhilarating cast, featuring seven performers who are themselves autistic young adults making their Broadway debuts portraying the autistic characters.

At the heart of the wonderfully performed but uneven musical ‘How to Dance in Ohio’ beats a reality for its key characters that is at once simple and profound...in the end, this worthwhile musical finds the steps to an upbeat last dance.
Generically staged by Sammi Cannold, ‘How to Dance in Ohio’ was clearly made with love and will touch some hearts—on the spectrum or not—but feels synthetic and patchy when not outright tacky.

“An object at rest stays at rest,” Liam sings in his final song, “Building Momentum,” which is a song about crafting one’s own destiny, the future that makes sense to you. And in the decisions and end-points of the characters on stage—and in their final rock-out dance and singing—that is the emphatic common theme.

“it is a welcome change that the seven autistic characters in ‘How to Dance in Ohio’ are presented, without condescension, as young adults a lot like most others, albeit with unusual gifts and challenges.

‘How to Dance in Ohio’ is certainly less raw and dispassionately observed than the movie. But this is not a documentary but a Broadway musical comedy, and as such engineered to meet the requirements of most popular entries in the genre today: uplift, sweetness, rainbow endings for all.

‘How to Dance in Ohio’ being on Broadway at all is a radical act, centering autistic experiences in a way that has never been done before...a vital step in the right direction, helping Broadway change for the better and become a more accepting, accessible, and autism-friendly place.

All of the actors playing autistic people publicly identify as autistic themselves; they’re also all making their Broadway debuts, and while some are more experienced than others—Pearce, with his expansively emotional voice, is a ringer—they all make winsome impressions.
The musical adaptation of Alexandra Shiva's 2015 documentary is a tender, authentic portrayal of young adults on the autism spectrum preparing for a spring formal dance.
Under director Sammi Cannold’s staging, the actors perform with verve, commitment and authenticity — and, in a few cases, show some real star power.

It’s a credit to ‘How to Dance in Ohio’s’ cast that they deliver compelling performances, even when their material gets rote and didactic...If we’re here to meet these characters who aren’t going to be stand-ins for generalized traits, let’s really spend the time to get to know them all.
The 'Harry Potter' star makes a winning J. Pierrepont Finch in the revival of 'How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.'
The production is slick and entertaining, even if it doesn't break much new ground.
Daniel Radcliffe brings boyish charm and surprising comic timing to the role of J. Pierrepont Finch, the window washer who climbs the corporate ladder through cunning and luck.
Rankcom's production suffers from pushing practically everything to cartoonish extremes; it becomes rather exhausting over a far-too-long runtime.

Daniel Radcliffe's J. Pierrepont Finch is certainly energetic, and his fans will no doubt be pleased to see him sing and dance his way through this classic musical comedy about corporate climbing.

“Erie is portrayed by that excellent actor Forest Whitaker, in a transfixing yet modest Broadway debut.…Mr. Whitaker quietly breaks your heart…I hope his performance isn’t under-appreciated because it lacks showy bravado…'Hughie' feels as vaporous as smoke, though the kind that might come from an opium pipe...

“Fans of Danny DeVito’s signature style of dramatic comedy will delight in this play...Still, it’s hard to imagine anyone growing attached to this show if they lack the nostalgic hunger to see a long-standing performer grapple with themes of remembrance or marvel at the rarity of seeing real-life relatives play onstage together. “

Clutter – physical, emotional – is the subject of Theresa Rebeck’s new Broadway play ‘I Need That’, a comedy-drama that stars Danny DeVito works mightily and with increasing futility to stuff with laughs and meaning.

Overall, this piece doesn’t land at the top of Rebeck’s impressively diverse oeuvre, and I’d wager you’ll see some things coming far faster than any fire department. But I’m partial to plays that deal with experiences almost everyone shares and throwing stuff out is far higher on the list of life traumas than you might think.

Rebeck sets up Sam’s hoarder scenario and backstory well enough early on. She just can’t build a satisfying play around the condition. Every step the character takes is totally predictable, until a few brow-raising twists that strain credulity.

‘DeVito’ is such a skilled performer that he makes the play watchable from beginning to end despite its frequent slow spots...he turns a lengthy scene in which he angrily plays Sorry by himself into a comedic tour de force.

‘I Need That’ runs only 100 intermission-free minutes, but somehow feels padded...There’s so much substance on stage, literally—Alexander Dodge’s set is a brilliant testament to the pure emotional power of material goods; less so in the script. Sorry!
I Need That runs only 100 intermission-free minutes, but somehow feels padded.

Theresa Rebeck’s play about a hoarder is the slightest of comedies. Its plot is paltry. Its insights are fleeting. It promises more laughs than it delivers. It even promises more junk than it delivers: Before the curtain rises, there’s a tantalizing pile-up of old papers and boxes resting on the lip of the stage.

The vintage board game Sorry! wasn't designed to be played alone. Leave it to Emmy winner Danny DeVito, who shines as the aimless widow Sam in ‘I Need That’, to turn the unlikely moment into a theatrical highlight that’s silly, sad, and, no joke, poetic.

“DeVito gets more mileage out of Sam than you’d expect from the page, performing with a loose, raffish panache...Funny pronunciation. Silly faces. Kooky obsessives behaving irrationally. It’s been the stuff of sitcoms for decades and popular for a reason.

To match the living circumstances of its lead character, the play feels a deflating mess, with puzzling performances and staging as if no one involved quite knows what it is—comedy, whimsy, or low-key tragedy? Of course, a play can be all those things, but I Need That jerks uneasily around many registers, never finding its heart, or dramatic or ...

I Need That is clearly a vehicle for DeVito’s return to Broadway, coming six years after his debut in Arthur Miller’s The Price. DeVito is funny and makes the most of Rebeck’s slapstick material. Within the ensemble and alone, he brings charm and occasional devastation to Sam’s afflictions.

It’s hard to imagine what more one could make of an upbeat play about hoarding. The first Broadway revival of Stephen Sondheim and George Furth’s notorious bomb explodes with heart and sophistication.

Not that this new production of ’Merrily’ completely fills in and smoothes out the musical’s legendary potholes, but it certainly helps us step around them without too much effort or frustration. You’d be hard-pressed to imagine a better ’Merrily Along’.

What’s most impressive: When they sing the anthem ‘Old Friends,’ they actually look like old friends. If you can, see this revival with an old friend—perhaps one who’s never experienced the many joys of ‘Merrily’ or heard its innumerable hummable songs. Yes, hummable.

In the end, there’s not a lot here: No crazy shark puppets, little sense of the raging seas nor of tormented, insecure actors — not much for the eye to see and very little happening that you don’t anticipate just five or 10 minutes into the show.

Incredibly, The Shark Is Broken aspires to similar depths despite its comedic trappings. On its surface, the 95-minute play is about the frustrations, petty rivalries, and not-so-secret vices that Scheider, Dreyfuss, and Shaw may have gotten up to while waiting for cameras to roll on Jaws.

In the end, there’s not a lot here: No crazy shark puppets, little sense of the raging seas nor of tormented, insecure actors — not much for the eye to see and very little happening that you don’t anticipate just five or 10 minutes into the show.
The three-man show is funny, fascinating and surprisingly moving as it dives into the psychology of three very different men stuck together on a sinking boat.

...the comfort that ‘The Shark Is Broken' brings, and it truly is a most enjoyable 95 minutes, stems from the canny way in which it channels Jaws itself...Watching ‘The Shark Is Broken,’ then, is not unlike diving into a boatload of outtakes from a beloved classic. If you’re anything like me, you eat it up like it’s popcorn.
As is the whole 95 minutes of three men—no, three actors with a broken mechanical shark—on a boat. All laughter, with no threat of a shark attack. ’Cause the shark is broken.

All three actors give uncanny impersonations that sometimes shade into nuanced portraits….The main question, though, is why do a backstage comedy about “Jaws” almost half a century after its release? The only obvious answer is that the show needed to wait until Robert Shaw’s son Ian got to be as old as his father was when he portrayed Quint… now...

‘The Shark Is Broken’ is all talk, and a pattern emerges. Shaw and Dreyfuss clash. Scheider referees. It gets repetitive over the 95-minute run time. On the plus side, there are moments when the warring trio clicks and a sort of camaraderie shines through. Plus, the co-authors seasoned the script with laughs.
...'The Shark Is Broken' isn’t an ambitious drama, just an unusual workplace dramedy with a genealogical twist.

The Shark is Broken’s scenic design is packed with memorabilia from the original film, including a floatation barrel used to track the fictional predator, but the real memories pay homage to Robert Shaw’s complicated life as an artist struggling with addiction.

‘The Shark Is Broken’ is a character study in which your level of interest will be tied to your curiosity about the trio of film actors being depicted here, all of them flummoxed by the many delays in shooting and lacking the knowledge of foresight about what ultimately will be the massive popularity and financial success of ‘Jaws’.
